grammarNote.title: は vs. が: Topic vs. Subject
grammarNote.explanation: This is one of the most important distinctions in Japanese. が marks NEW information (something just noticed or discovered): 貝殻があった！ (A shell was [there]! — discovery). は marks KNOWN information being commented on: この貝殻はいい (This shell [that we're looking at] is nice). A useful test: if you could say 'As for X...' naturally, use は. If the sentence answers 'who/what did it?', use が.

examples.japanese: 貝殻 が あった！
examples.english: There was a shell! (new discovery — が)

examples.japanese: この 貝殻 は いい！
examples.english: This shell is nice! (known topic — は)

examples.japanese: スナフキン は いい 人 だ ね。
examples.english: Snufkin is a good person, isn't he.

vocabulary.example: ああ、いい 貝殻 だ。
モラン が いた！
もう 貝殻 が あった！

vocabulary.meaning: to be visible, can be seen
vocabulary.example: なに が 見える？
貝殻 が あった！

storyNote: Sandy shore near the sea. Shells scattered on the beach. Waves. Mountains visible in the background. A dark silhouette (the Groke) far away.
